content.title: Frontotemporal Dementia
content.summary: Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is a clinically and pathologically heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative disorders primarily affecting the frontal and temporal lobes, characterized by progressive changes in behavior, personality, and/or language, typically with younger onset (45-65 years) and relative sparing of memory early in the disease course.
key_points: Second most common cause of early-onset dementia (after Alzheimer's)
Three main clinical variants: behavioral (bvFTD), semantic (svPPA), nonfluent (nfvPPA)
bvFTD: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive behaviors
Memory relatively preserved early; personality/behavior changes predominate
30-50% have genetic cause (C9orf72, MAPT, GRN mutations)
MRI shows focal frontal and/or temporal atrophy; 'knife-edge' gyri
content.statement: Frontotemporal dementia is a neurodegenerative syndrome characterized by progressive deterioration of behavior, personality, and/or language due to selective frontal and temporal lobe degeneration, with typically younger onset and initial preservation of episodic memory.

explanation.intuition: While Alzheimer's attacks memory first, FTD attacks the parts of the brain that make us 'who we are' - our personality, social behavior, and language. A patient with FTD might forget social rules, act inappropriately, or lose the meaning of words, while still remembering their grandchildren's names.
explanation.key_insight: The three clinical variants reflect different anatomical patterns: behavioral variant (frontal lobe) causes disinhibition and apathy; semantic variant (anterior temporal) causes loss of word/object meaning; nonfluent variant (left perisylvian) causes effortful, agrammatic speech.
explanation.technical_details: FTD pathology is classified as FTLD-tau (4R or 3R tauopathies including Pick's disease, PSP, CBD), FTLD-TDP (types A-E), or FTLD-FUS. C9orf72 hexanucleotide repeat expansion is the most common genetic cause and can present with FTD, ALS, or both.

definitions_glossary.frontotemporal_dementia: Clinical syndrome of frontal/temporal neurodegeneration causing behavior/language changes
definitions_glossary.behavioral_variant_FTD: bvFTD; characterized by personality changes, disinhibition, apathy
definitions_glossary.semantic_variant_PPA: svPPA; progressive loss of word and object meaning with fluent empty speech
definitions_glossary.nonfluent_variant_PPA: nfvPPA; effortful, agrammatic speech with intact comprehension
definitions_glossary.primary_progressive_aphasia: PPA; progressive language disorder with three subtypes
definitions_glossary.disinhibition: Loss of normal social restraint; inappropriate behavior
definitions_glossary.executive_dysfunction: Impaired planning, judgment, organization from frontal lobe damage
definitions_glossary.C9orf72: Gene with hexanucleotide repeat expansion causing FTD and/or ALS
definitions_glossary.MAPT: Microtubule-associated protein tau gene; mutations cause tau-related FTD
definitions_glossary.GRN: Progranulin gene; mutations cause TDP-43 pathology FTD
definitions_glossary.Pick_bodies: Spherical tau inclusions characteristic of Pick's disease
definitions_glossary.FTLD: Frontotemporal lobar degeneration; pathological term for FTD
definitions_glossary.knife_edge_atrophy: Severe focal gyral atrophy seen on MRI in FTD

pathophysiology.mechanism: Selective neurodegeneration of frontal and temporal cortices with protein aggregation

FTLD_FUS.features: Typically sporadic, younger onset, neuronal intermediate filament inclusions

genes.C9orf72: Most common; hexanucleotide repeat expansion; FTD + ALS spectrum

behavioral_features: Early loss of sympathy or empathy
Executive/generation deficits with relative sparing of memory and visuospatial

imaging.MRI: Focal frontal and/or temporal atrophy; knife-edge gyri

differential_diagnosis: Progressive supranuclear palsy and corticobasal syndrome (overlap with FTD)

behavioral_symptoms.SSRIs: Trazodone, sertraline for disinhibition, compulsive behaviors
behavioral_symptoms.antipsychotics: Low-dose quetiapine if needed; use cautiously

symptomatic_management.speech_therapy: For language variants; augmentative communication devices

supportive_care: Advance care planning early in disease
treatment_options.genetic_counseling: For patients with family history or confirmed mutations
treatment_options.clinical_trials: Encourage enrollment in FTD research trials

definition.@value: A heterogeneous group of neurodegenerative disorders affecting frontal and temporal lobes, characterized by progressive changes in behavior, personality, and/or language

scopeNote.@value: Covers clinical variants, pathology, genetics, and symptomatic management of FTD

learning_objectives: Distinguish frontotemporal dementia from Alzheimer's disease clinically
Identify the three main clinical variants of FTD
Recognize behavioral features diagnostic of bvFTD
Understand the genetic basis of FTD including C9orf72 expansion
clinical_pearls: Memory preserved early + personality change + younger onset = think FTD, not AD
Disinhibition + apathy + compulsive eating = bvFTD triad
C9orf72 expansion can cause both FTD and ALS - screen family for both
Cholinesterase inhibitors may WORSEN behavioral symptoms in FTD
SSRIs (especially trazodone) are first-line for behavioral management
common_misconceptions: FTD is rare - it's the second most common early-onset dementia
Memory loss is always first in dementia - behavior/language dominate in FTD
FTD patients lack insight - some variants preserve insight early
